node.text: Twenty million people are under heat alerts in the Western United States. As scorching temperatures bring drought, water restrictions and wildfires, these residents say they've had enough.

node.title: These Americans are fleeing the West because of extreme heat

node.text: One Maine-based startup, Running Tide Technologies, is experimenting with farming kelp, a type of seaweed, in an effort to pull carbon from the air and store it deep beneath the ocean floor, potentially giving the world another nature-based tool to curb climate change.

node.title: This startup wants to pull carbon from the air using kelp

node.text: Russia's Lake Baikal is the oldest and deepest lake in the world, holding about 20% of the world's fresh water and currently facing increasing environmental threats from climate change and mass tourism. As Russia continues to encourage visitors to the lake, even in the midst of the pandemic, some locals question whether the pristine environment is being sacrificed in favor of revenue. CNN's @fpleitgencnn reports from a town in Russia, where some say their home simply can't take on any more people.

node.title: 'This is certainly one of those an environmental ticking time bomb'

node.text: In the north woods of Minnesota, around the frozen Mississippi River, a small-but-growing group of protesters is out to stop a replacement oil pipeline called Line 3. Tribal activists, environmentalists and local residents have build temporary protest camps along the construction route.

node.title: The next Keystone XL fight is here in Minnesota

node.text: San Francisco-based startup, Compology, is using cameras and artificial intelligence to monitor what’s thrown into dumpsters and trash containers at businesses such as McDonald’s restaurants and Nordstrom department stores.

node.text: Global honey bee populations are in decline, putting the world's food supply under pressure. Texas beekeeper Erika Thompson is on a mission to save them, and the videos of her rescue missions have TikTok users buzzing.

node.title: This beekeeper is on a mission to save the bees

node.text: Dams that beavers build can reduce flooding and drought, increase biodiversity, and lower pollution. They were hunted to extinction across Europe for their pelts -- but now they're being reintroduced into the wild in England, and their impact is remarkable

node.text: Methane, or natural gas, is 80 times more potent than carbon dioxide. @billweircnn goes to Texas, where methane is so plentiful and cheap, it escaped largely unseen and unmeasured until recently.

node.title: An invisible gas is pitting Texas against the Biden administration

node.text: With President Biden expected to sign several climate-focused executive actions Wednesday, CNN's Bill Weir looks at the state of the climate crisis using an infrared camera to show methane, a gas 80 times more potent than carbon dioxide, polluting clear blue sky over Texas.

node.title: How President Biden plans to target the climate crisis

node.text: Gillette, Wyoming, is the energy capital of the United States. After the election, resident Steve Gray left CNN a voicemail saying he feared Gillette will become a ghost town under President Joe Biden. CNN contributor John Sutter travels to Gillette to meet Steve and asks: In the fight against the climate crisis, what do we owe the workers who have helped power America for decades?

node.title: This town powered America. Now what?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 20, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Climate The Bootleg Fire in Oregon is so large, it's creating its own weather'.

node.text:
The Bootleg Fire in Oregon has become so intense that it is creating its own weather. The fire has scorched 537 square miles -- an area larger than Los Angeles and about half the size of Rhode Island. Hot, dry weather conditions continue to fuel wildfires across much of the United States, and the Bootleg Fire grew to nearly 364,113 acres Monday and is 30% contained, Oregon Department of Forestry spokesperson Marcus Kauffman told CNN. The climate crisis has made deadlier and more destructive wildfires the new normal. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Mathieu Lewis-Rolland/Reuters)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 19, 2021. May be an image of nature and text that says 'Welcome to to California'.

node.text:
Dozens of large wildfires are raging across the western US as the region experiences a historic and unrelenting drought. The biggest right now is the Bootleg Fire along the Oregon and California border. As of Monday, it had burned more than 300,000 acres. 

(📸: US Forest Service/ZUMA Press Wire, Noah Berger/AP, Josh Edelson/AFP/Getty Images and Ty O'Neil/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

node.text: Looking back to all the Olympic Games dating to 1984 in Los Angeles, Tokyo's average high temperature is warmest and it is also the wettest for the two weeks of competition. The average temperature combined with humidity in Tokyo has the potential to make these games feel even hotter than Atlanta and Athens. Tokyo is also threatened by typhoons, which can bring torrential rain, high winds and flash flooding. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Climate The Amazon is emitting more CO2 than it absorbs in some areas, study says'.

node.text:
Parts of the Amazon rainforest are now emitting more carbon dioxide than they absorb, raising fears of the potentially devastating impact on its fragile ecosystems and a further worsening of the climate crisis, according to a study. The research, published Wednesday in the scientific journal Nature, says the Amazon's vital role as a carbon sink — absorbing massive amounts of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, helping to cool the Earth — is under threat. "This carbon sink seems to be in decline," the study said. "Over the past 40 years, eastern Amazonia has been subjected to more deforestation, warming and moisture stress than the western part, especially during the dry season." Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
⁠
(📸: Florence Goisnard/AFP/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 16, 2021. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'Climate Record rainfall leaves over 120 dead in western Europe, devastating parts of Germany'.

node.text:
Catastrophic flooding in western Europe has killed more than 100 people, with hundreds more missing, authorities said Friday, as large-scale rescue efforts continue amidst rising water, landslides and power outages. Shocking images of the devastation in Germany and Belgium showed entire villages underwater, with cars wedged in between collapsed buildings and debris. Extreme rainfall is becoming more common in the warming climate, as warmer air can hold more water vapor that is available to fall as rain. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Rhein-Erft District/@Bezregkoeln/Twitter)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Climate The European Union has announced plans to end the sale of polluting vehicles by 2035.'.

node.text:
The European Union has announced plans to end the sale of polluting vehicles by 2035, an ambitious goal that would put hybrid cars on the endangered species list and usher in a rapid and dramatic shift to fully electric models. The European Commission said Wednesday that it wants to require the auto industry to slash the average emissions of new cars by 55% by 2030. A further reduction to 100% by 2035 effectively means that all new cars registered from that year onward must be zero-emission vehicles. The United Kingdom has already made a similar commitment. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Florian Gaertner/Photosthek/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 14, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Climate Moon wobble to bring surge in coastal flooding in 2030s, NASA study predicts'.

node.text:
A dramatic surge in high-tide floods is just over a decade away in the United States, according to NASA. The rapid increase will start in the mid-2030s, when a lunar cycle will amplify rising sea levels caused by the climate crisis, found a new study by the NASA Sea Level Change Science Team from the University of Hawaii. Only far northern coastlines, such as Alaska's, will get at least another decade's respite because long-term geological processes are leading to these land areas rising. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Bruce Bennett/Getty Images)⁠

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 13, 2021. May be an image of fire and text that says 'Climate California fires this year have scorched 3 times more land than during last year's season'.

node.text:
A severe drought, coupled with human-induced climate change, has resulted in a fire season that has already seen more than three times as much land burned in California so far this year than during the same time span last year, officials said Monday. The state recorded its worst fire season ever in 2020, with more than 4.2 million estimated acres burned. As of Monday, 142,477 acres have been scorched in the state, which is 103,588 more acres than during the same time period last year, Cal Fire said in a tweet. Tap the link in our bio to learn more. ⁠
⁠
(📸: Ty ONeil/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 12, 2021. May be an image of sky and text that says 'Climate Western wildfires have burned an area 4 times the size of NYC'.

node.text:
The National Interagency Fire Center says 55 large fires have burned over 768,000 acres across 12 states – that's four times the area of New York City. Fires in California have charred thousands of acres, more than doubling the amount burned for the same time period last year.⁠
⁠
(📸: Noah Berger/AP)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 12, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Climate Extreme heat cooked mussels and clams alive on Canadian beaches'.

node.text:
The devastating heat wave that ravaged British Columbia last week is being blamed for a massive die-off of mussels, clams and other marine animals that live on the beaches of Western Canada. Mussels attach themselves to rocks and other surfaces and are used to being exposed to the air and sunlight during low tide but they generally can't survive temperatures over 100 degrees for very long, said Christopher Harley, a professor in the zoology department at The University of British Columbia. ⁠
⁠
(📸: Courtesy Christopher Harley

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Climate Dragonflies are losing their wing color because of climate change, study shows'.

node.text:
Male dragonflies are adapting to a warmer climate by losing the ornate black patterns on their wings, which they typically use to attract female mates, according to research published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. Researchers worry that female species may no longer recognize their male counterparts without their intricate wing patterns and, thus, won't be able to reproduce as temperatures get hotter. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Ron Reznick/VW Pics/Universal Images Group/Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CNN Climate on July 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Climate Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak: 'It's time to recognize the right to repair''.

node.text:
Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak is showing his support for the "right to repair" movement. Wozniak spoke out on the issue during a recent appearance on Cameo, a website that lets fans pay celebrities for video messages. In a post to Louis Rossmann, a YouTube personality and a right-to-repair advocate, Wozniak said that he was "totally supportive" of the cause — which gives consumers the right and information to fix their own devices — and somewhat "emotionally" affected by it. The right to repair movement has gained ground lately. In the United Kingdom, new measures have been introduced to require manufacturers of televisions, washing machines and refrigerators to provide spare parts to consumers. Building new devices takes a lot of energy. For example, 83% of the iPhone 12's life cycle carbon emissions occurs during the production, extraction and transportation of raw materials. Tap the link in our bio to learn more.⁠
⁠
(📸: Lachlan Cunningham/Getty Images)
